questions.text: A young patient came with complaints of acute abdominal pain on and off and tingling sensation of limbs and at times weakness of limbs. She had a history of eating paint from the wall of a newly built house. Which of the following enzyme defect will be the cause of her condition? ( AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) ALA dehydratase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lead poisoning inhibits ALA dehydratase, causing symptoms such as abdominal pain, tingling, and weakness of limbs. Paint ingestion, particularly in children, is a significant source of lead exposure.

questions.text: Which of the following zymogens requires gamma-glutamyl carboxylase? (NEET PG 2023)

options.label: B
options.text: Factors II, VII, IX, and X

questions.correct_answer: B. Factors II, VII, IX, and X
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Factors II, VII, IX, and X

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Zymogens are the proprotein form of enzymes (proenzymes) that require proteolytic activation to carry out their function.
  • ➤ Inactive form of vitamin K acts as a cofactor in the post-synthetic modification of these zymogens and their activation. This inactive form of vitamin K is recycled back from its oxidized form by the enzyme vitamin K epoxide reductase, which can be inhibited by warfarin or liver failure.

questions.text: Which is not a product of heme catabolism? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Aminolaevulinic acid

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Aminolaevulinic acid is a precursor in the synthesis of heme, not a product of its catabolism.

questions.text: Complex 4 inhibitor is? ( NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Cyanide

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Cyanide is a potent inhibitor of Complex IV (cytochrome c oxidase) in the electron transport chain (ETC). Complex IV is crucial for the final step of the electron transport chain, where it facilitates the transfer of electrons to oxygen, the final electron acceptor, to form water. By inhibiting Complex IV, cyanide prevents the reduction of oxygen, halting ATP production and leading to cellular hypoxia and energy failure.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Carbon Dioxide: Carbon dioxide is not an inhibitor of any of the electron transport chain complexes. It is a byproduct of cellular respiration and does not interfere with the function of the ETC complexes.
  • • Option B. Carbon Dioxide:
  • • Option C. Oligomycin: Oligomycin is an inhibitor of ATP synthase (Complex V) in the electron transport chain. It binds to the F0 subunit of ATP synthase, blocking the proton channel and preventing proton translocation across the inner mitochondrial membrane. This inhibition halts ATP synthesis from ADP and inorganic phosphate.
  • • Option C. Oligomycin:
  • • Option D. Antimycin: Antimycin is an inhibitor of Complex III (cytochrome bc1 complex) in the electron transport chain. It binds to the Qi site of cytochrome c reductase, blocking the transfer of electrons from ubiquinol to cytochrome c, disrupting the proton gradient and halting ATP synthesis.
  • • Option D. Antimycin:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Inhibitor of ETC complexes
  • ➤ Inhibitor of ETC complexes

References:

  • ↳ Reference : Harper’s 31 st ed/pg- 123

questions.text: Which amino acid possesses a positive charge at physiological pH? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Arginine, at physiological pH (around 7.4), maintains a positive charge. This is due to its side chain which contains a guanidino group capable of accepting protons. The guanidino group in arginine is a strong base, resulting in a higher pKa value compared to other amino acids, and thus remains protonated and positively charged at physiological pH. This property is essential for its roles in protein interactions and metabolic functions.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • a. Valine: This is a nonpolar amino acid with no charge on its side chain at physiological pH. b. Aspartic acid: This amino acid has a carboxyl group in its side chain that is deprotonated and negatively charged at physiological pH. d. Isoleucine: Similar to valine, isoleucine is a nonpolar amino acid with a neutral side chain at physiological pH.
  • • a. Valine: This is a nonpolar amino acid with no charge on its side chain at physiological pH.
  • • a. Valine:
  • • b. Aspartic acid: This amino acid has a carboxyl group in its side chain that is deprotonated and negatively charged at physiological pH.
  • • b. Aspartic acid:
  • • d. Isoleucine: Similar to valine, isoleucine is a nonpolar amino acid with a neutral side chain at physiological pH.
  • • d. Isoleucine:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Arginine is distinct among the common amino acids due to its positively charged guanidino group at physiological pH, which plays a crucial role in protein structure and function.

questions.text: Liver produces KB but cannot use KB due to absence of which enzyme: (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The liver plays a crucial role in ketone body metabolism. During periods of prolonged fasting or low carbohydrate intake, the liver produces ketone bodies (acetoacetate and β-hydroxybutyrate) through a process called ketogenesis. These ketone bodies are then released into the bloodstream and can be used as an alternative fuel source by various tissues, including the brain, heart, and skeletal muscles.

questions.text: Which of the following amino acid is necessary for conversion of nor-epinephrine to epinephrine? (NEET PG 2019)

Ans. D) Methionine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Norepinephrine is methylated by the enzyme N-methyl transferase (NMT) to epinephrine or adrenaline.
  • ➤ Norepinephrine is methylated by the enzyme N-methyl transferase (NMT) to epinephrine
  • ➤ S-adenosyl methionine (SAM) is the methyl donor . It is mainly produced by adrenal medulla and adrenergic nerve endings. It is stored in chromaffin granules and released into blood.

questions.text: Banding technique used for dicentric chromosomes: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) C

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Dicentric chromosome is an abnormal chromosome with two centromeres.
  • • C banding : stains heterochromatin which are regions of the chromosomes at or near centromere. So, C banding will be most useful for dicentric chromosomes.
  • • C banding
  • • So, C banding will be most useful for dicentric chromosomes.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. G-banding: G-banding is the most common banding technique and uses Giemsa stain to stain AT-rich regions. It was developed as an alternative to Q-banding due to the cumbersome nature of Q-banding.
  • • Option A. G-banding:
  • • Option B. NOR-banding: NOR-banding (Nucleolar Organizer Region) is used to stain regions associated with nucleolus formation and is not specifically useful for dicentric chromosomes.
  • • Option B. NOR-banding:
  • • Option D. R-banding: R-banding provides a reverse pattern to G-banding, staining GC-rich regions instead of AT-rich regions. It is not specifically useful for identifying dicentric chromosomes.
  • • Option D. R-banding:
  • • Note – Q banding : uses quinacrine dye (first used dye) and stains repetitive AT rich regions.
  • • Note – Q banding

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ C-banding is the preferred technique for identifying dicentric chromosomes as it specifically stains heterochromatin regions at or near the centromere.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: Robbins 10th Ed. / page- 262-263, 293

questions.text: A young male with a H/o dyslipidemia having ABC-A1 mutation shows the following. See the image and tell the diagnosis. ( INICET Nov 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Tangier’s disease / Hypo alpha lipoproteinemia
  • ➤ Tangier’s disease / Hypo alpha lipoproteinemia
  • ➤ ABC-A1 transporters are required for efflux of intracellular free cholesterol and phospholipids across the plasma membrane to combine with apolipoproteins, forming nascent high-density lipoprotein-cholesterol (HDL-C) particles (see fig).
  • ➤ So, in case of defective ABC-A1, HDL cholesterol and PL are not exported, and HDL is not properly formed causing HDL↓ (Hypo alpha-lipoproteinemia). Cholesterol accumulates in reticuloendothelial system causing: Hepatosplenomegaly Enlarged lymph nodes Large orange/ yellow tonsils (due to fat deposition) The characteristic feature of Wolman’s disease is calcification of adrenals . It is also known as cholesterol ester storage disease and occurs due to deficiency of enzyme acid lipase
  • ➤ So, in case of defective ABC-A1, HDL cholesterol and PL are not exported, and HDL is not properly formed causing HDL↓ (Hypo alpha-lipoproteinemia).
  • ➤ Cholesterol accumulates in reticuloendothelial system causing: Hepatosplenomegaly Enlarged lymph nodes Large orange/ yellow tonsils (due to fat deposition)
  • ➤ Hepatosplenomegaly Enlarged lymph nodes Large orange/ yellow tonsils (due to fat deposition)
  • ➤ Hepatosplenomegaly
  • ➤ Enlarged lymph nodes
  • ➤ Large orange/ yellow tonsils (due to fat deposition)
  • ➤ The characteristic feature of Wolman’s disease is calcification of adrenals . It is also known as cholesterol ester storage disease and occurs due to deficiency of enzyme acid lipase
  • ➤ calcification of adrenals

questions.text: A newborn presents on the 5th day of life with vomiting, severe jaundice, and an inability to tolerate breast milk, although the infant accepts glucose water without issue. Laboratory tests reveal hypoglycemia, a positive Benedict’s test for reducing substances in the urine, and elevated unconjugated bilirubin levels. On examination, the liver is enlarged. What enzyme deficiency is the most likely cause of these symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase (GALT) deficiency is the cause of classic galactosemia, an autosomal recessive disorder characterized by an inability to metabolize galactose due to a defect in the enzyme responsible for converting galactose-1-phosphate into glucose-1-phosphate. This deficiency leads to the accumulation of toxic substances such as galactose-1-phosphate in the liver, brain, and other organs, resulting in hypoglycemia, jaundice, hepatomegaly, and potential mental retardation if untreated. The positive Benedict’s test, jaundice, and refusal of lactose-containing feeds are hallmark findings of this condition. Early diagnosis and dietary management by eliminating galactose and lactose from the diet are crucial to prevent severe complications.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • A. Fructokinase deficiency: Fructokinase deficiency, also known as essential fructosuria, is a benign condition where fructose is not metabolized efficiently, leading to its excretion in the urine. It does not cause severe systemic symptoms like jaundice or hypoglycemia seen in GALT deficiency.
  • • A. Fructokinase deficiency:
  • • C. Phosphoglucomutase deficiency: This enzyme deficiency affects glycogen metabolism but does not directly involve galactose metabolism and does not present with the typical symptoms of classic galactosemia, such as vomiting, jaundice, or hepatomegaly.
  • • C. Phosphoglucomutase deficiency:
  • • D. Sorbitol dehydrogenase deficiency: Sorbitol dehydrogenase deficiency affects the metabolism of sorbitol and fructose, leading to cataracts and osmotic imbalances but does not cause severe systemic symptoms like jaundice or hypoglycemia seen in GALT deficiency.
  • • D. Sorbitol dehydrogenase deficiency:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase (GALT) deficiency, or classic galactosemia, is a severe metabolic disorder marked by an inability to properly metabolize galactose, leading to serious systemic symptoms including jaundice, hypoglycemia, and liver dysfunction. Early diagnosis and management through a lactose-free diet are crucial for preventing long-term complications such as mental retardation, emphasizing the importance of newborn screening and prompt intervention in suspected cases of galactosemia.

questions.text: A 35-year-old Farmer on maize diet with diarrhoea, dementia, and dermatitis. Which Vitamin is deficient in this patient? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Niacin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The major protein of Maize, “Zein” lacks tryptophan which is required for Niacin biosynthesis. 60 mg of tryptophan gives 1 mg of Niacin in the body. So, pellagra is more common when maize is the staple diet due to decreased synthesis of Niacin. Pellagra is characterized by 3Ds i.e. diarrhoea, dementia and dermatitis. Death and delirium and depression can also occur.
  • ➤ Pellagra can also be caused due to Isoniazid therapy as isoniazid inhibits PLP (B6) formation which in turn is required for Niacin synthesis. Vitamin B2 is also required for Niacin synthesis, so, a deficiency either of B2 or B6 or both can cause pellagra.
  • ➤ Thiamine (B1) deficiency leads to Beri-Beri. CNS and CVS are affected in dry Beri-Beri and wet Beri-Beri respectively.
  • ➤ Main symptoms of Riboflavin deficiency are Cheilosis, Glossitis and Corneal vascularization.
  • ➤ Pyridoxine deficiency cause anemia (microcytic, hypochromic) and seizures in infants.
  • ➤ Ref -Harper 31 st e/pg. 534-535
  • ➤ Ref -Harper 31 st e/pg. 534-535

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Animal products

Educational Objective:

questions.text: True regarding CF (Cystic Fibrosis): ( INICET Nov 2023)

options.label: A
options.text: Chloride secretion is decreased in sweat and increased in pancreatic fluid

options.label: B
options.text: Chloride secretion is increased in sweat and decreased in pancreatic fluid

options.label: C
options.text: Chloride secretion is decreased in both sweat and pancreatic fluid

options.label: D
options.text: Chloride secretion is increased in both sweat and pancreatic fluid

questions.correct_answer: B. Chloride secretion is increased in sweat and decreased in pancreatic fluid
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • In sweat glands, the defective CFTR leads to decreased chloride reabsorption, resulting in increased chloride secretion in sweat. Therefore, individuals with CF have elevated levels of chloride in their sweat, which is a diagnostic feature of the condition.
  • • In the pancreas, the impaired CFTR function leads to decreased chloride secretion into pancreatic fluid. This results in the production of thick, sticky mucus in the pancreatic ducts, leading to pancreatic insufficiency. The pancreas is unable to release digestive enzymes properly into the small intestine, affecting the digestion of food.
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Cystic Fibrosis (CF) is a genetic disorder caused by mutations in the CFTR (Cystic Fibrosis Transmembrane Conductance Regulator) gene. CFTR is a chloride channel that regulates the movement of chloride ions across cell membranes. In individuals with cystic fibrosis, the function of CFTR is impaired.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with recurrent episodes of abdominal pain, pancreatitis, and creamy plasma on laboratory analysis. Genetic testing confirms a diagnosis of lipoprotein lipase deficiency. Following the consumption of a fatty meal, which substance is most likely to be significantly elevated in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • In lipoprotein lipase (LPL) deficiency, chylomicrons accumulate in the blood, particularly after consuming a fatty meal. LPL is essential for the hydrolysis of triglycerides present in chylomicrons into free fatty acids, which can be used for energy or stored in tissues. When LPL is deficient or non-functional, chylomicrons are not adequately broken down and thus accumulate in the bloodstream, causing hypertriglyceridemia, abdominal pain, and a higher risk of pancreatitis. This accumulation is especially noticeable after eating foods rich in fats, as chylomicrons are responsible for the transport of dietary triglycerides.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • A. Apolipoprotein B: Apolipoprotein B is a component of VLDL, LDL, and chylomicrons, but its levels do not specifically indicate LPL deficiency. The primary issue in LPL deficiency is the inability to clear triglyceride-rich lipoproteins, rather than a direct effect on apolipoprotein B.
  • • A. Apolipoprotein B:
  • • C. Lipoprotein (a): Lipoprotein (a) is a genetically determined lipoprotein that is associated with an increased risk of cardiovascular disease. It is not directly involved in triglyceride metabolism or affected by LPL deficiency.
  • • C. Lipoprotein (a):
  • • D. Sphingomyelin: Sphingomyelin is a type of phospholipid found in cell membranes and lipoproteins, but it is not directly related to triglyceride metabolism or influenced by LPL activity.
  • • D. Sphingomyelin:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lipoprotein lipase (LPL) deficiency leads to the accumulation of chylomicrons after consuming a fatty meal due to the inability to hydrolyze triglycerides effectively. This enzyme deficiency results in hypertriglyceridemia, which can cause symptoms like abdominal pain and pancreatitis. Understanding the specific lipoproteins affected in lipid metabolism disorders is crucial for accurate diagnosis and management.

questions.text: Cystic fibrosis is caused by which of the following deletion? ( INICET Nov 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Phenylalanine at 508

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Cystic fibrosis is due to mutation in cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) protein by deletion of one codon which give rise to phenylalanine at position 508 of this protein. Mnemonic: F-fibrosis, F- Phenylalaine
  • ➤ This protein helps in movement of H 2 O and chloride ion in and out of cell and helps in the formation of mucus secretion and saliva.
  • ➤ In normal conditions, the channel allows the formation of thin layer of mucus. But in cystic fibrosis, a thick layer of mucus is formed (see fig) causing airway obstruction leading to infection and ultimately scarring of lung tissue.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child came with complaints of pain over the right lower quadrant and lower back pain. On examination, he had pain over the right side of the hip on passive extension along with a mass in the right lumbar region pointing towards the groin. What is the most likely diagnosis? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.explanation:

  • ➤ The history of lower back pain needs to be evaluated with the possibility of tubercular origin to be kept in mind in this patient.

  • ➤ Treatment is usually by percutaneous CT-guided drainage and appropriate antibiotic therapy.

questions.text: A woman on anti-depressants presents with bleeding. She gives a history of bulky stools which sticks to the pan. Which of the following vitamin deficiency can cause bleeding in this condition? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Vitamin K

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Bulky, greasy stools that stick to the pan (often described as "steatorrhea") can be indicative of malabsorption, a condition where the absorption of nutrients, including fat-soluble vitamins, is impaired. Vitamin K is a fat-soluble vitamin crucial for the synthesis of blood clotting factors in the liver. Deficiency of vitamin K can lead to impaired blood clotting and a tendency to bleed .
  • ➤ .
  • ➤ Vitamin K is a fat-soluble vitamin crucial for the synthesis of blood clotting factors in the liver. Deficiency of vitamin K can lead to impaired blood clotting and a tendency to bleed.Top of Form

questions.text: Which component is most abundant in HDL compared to other lipoproteins? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • High-Density Lipoprotein (HDL) is distinguished from other lipoproteins by its high proportion of apoproteins. This higher protein content contributes to its higher density, which is reflected in its nomenclature. HDL's primary role is to transport cholesterol from the tissues back to the liver, a process known as reverse cholesterol transport. The abundance of apoproteins in HDL is crucial for this function, as these proteins serve as structural components and also play critical roles in lipoprotein metabolism and function.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • a. Cholesterol: While HDL carries cholesterol, it is not the lipoprotein with the highest proportion of cholesterol; that distinction belongs to Low-Density Lipoprotein (LDL). c. Triglycerides: HDL contains lower levels of triglycerides compared to Very Low-Density Lipoproteins (VLDL) and chylomicrons, which primarily transport triglycerides from the intestines and liver. d. Fatty acids: Fatty acids are not a primary component of HDL; they are more associated with VLDL and chylomicrons in terms of transport and function.
  • • a. Cholesterol: While HDL carries cholesterol, it is not the lipoprotein with the highest proportion of cholesterol; that distinction belongs to Low-Density Lipoprotein (LDL).
  • • a. Cholesterol:
  • • c. Triglycerides: HDL contains lower levels of triglycerides compared to Very Low-Density Lipoproteins (VLDL) and chylomicrons, which primarily transport triglycerides from the intestines and liver.
  • • c. Triglycerides:
  • • d. Fatty acids: Fatty acids are not a primary component of HDL; they are more associated with VLDL and chylomicrons in terms of transport and function.
  • • d. Fatty acids:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ HDL is characterized by a high proportion of apoproteins, which are critical for its role in reverse cholesterol transport and cardiovascular health.

questions.text: Which among the following organs has the least arteriovenous oxygen difference? ( INICET Nov 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Kidney

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The kidney has the least arteriovenous oxygen difference among the given organs due to its primary function of blood filtration, which requires relatively low oxygen extraction. This results in a low A-V O2 difference compared to organs like the brain and liver that have higher metabolic and oxygen consumption demands.

questions.text: A 21-year-old primigravida presents to the antenatal OPD. Her school going nephew who lives in the same house has contracted varicella. A blood sample is taken for Antibodies against varicella. The report is negative. What does this signify? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Susceptible to chicken pox

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Chickenpox in Pregnancy:
  • • Chickenpox in Pregnancy:
  • • Pregnant women with uncertain or no previous history of chickenpox, who have been exposed to the infection, should have a blood test to determine their immunity to Varicella-Zoster Virus (VZV). A negative antibody test indicates that the woman is not immune to VZV and is susceptible to chickenpox. If a pregnant woman is not immune and has had significant exposure, she is at risk of developing chickenpox and should be administered varicella-zoster immunoglobulin (VZIG). VZIG is effective up to 10 days after contact. Symptomatic treatment of chickenpox in pregnancy includes: Oral Acyclovir if within 24 hours of the onset of the rash and if the gestational age is greater than 20 weeks. Intravenous Acyclovir should be given to all pregnant women with severe chickenpox. VZIG has no therapeutic benefit once chickenpox has started. Women who develop chickenpox in pregnancy should be referred to a fetal medicine specialist at 16–20 weeks or 5 weeks after infection to look for congenital varicella syndrome. If the infection occurs in the last 4 weeks of pregnancy, there is a risk of varicella infection in the newborn. Planned delivery should normally be avoided for at least 7 days after the onset of the maternal rash to allow for the passive transfer of antibodies from mother to child.
  • • Pregnant women with uncertain or no previous history of chickenpox, who have been exposed to the infection, should have a blood test to determine their immunity to Varicella-Zoster Virus (VZV).
  • • A negative antibody test indicates that the woman is not immune to VZV and is susceptible to chickenpox.
  • • If a pregnant woman is not immune and has had significant exposure, she is at risk of developing chickenpox and should be administered varicella-zoster immunoglobulin (VZIG).
  • • VZIG is effective up to 10 days after contact.
  • • Symptomatic treatment of chickenpox in pregnancy includes: Oral Acyclovir if within 24 hours of the onset of the rash and if the gestational age is greater than 20 weeks. Intravenous Acyclovir should be given to all pregnant women with severe chickenpox.
  • • Oral Acyclovir if within 24 hours of the onset of the rash and if the gestational age is greater than 20 weeks. Intravenous Acyclovir should be given to all pregnant women with severe chickenpox.
  • • Oral Acyclovir if within 24 hours of the onset of the rash and if the gestational age is greater than 20 weeks.
  • • Intravenous Acyclovir should be given to all pregnant women with severe chickenpox.
  • • VZIG has no therapeutic benefit once chickenpox has started.
  • • Women who develop chickenpox in pregnancy should be referred to a fetal medicine specialist at 16–20 weeks or 5 weeks after infection to look for congenital varicella syndrome.
  • • If the infection occurs in the last 4 weeks of pregnancy, there is a risk of varicella infection in the newborn. Planned delivery should normally be avoided for at least 7 days after the onset of the maternal rash to allow for the passive transfer of antibodies from mother to child.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Immune to chickenpox: A negative antibody test does not signify immunity; it signifies susceptibility.
  • • Option B. Immune to chickenpox:
  • • Option C. Susceptible to zoster: Varicella-zoster virus causes both chickenpox (primary infection) and shingles (reactivation). A negative test for varicella antibodies indicates susceptibility to the primary infection (chickenpox), not to shingles.
  • • Option C. Susceptible to zoster:
  • • Option D. Immune to zoster: Immunity to zoster would imply prior exposure to the varicella-zoster virus, which is not indicated by a negative varicella antibody test.
  • • Option D. Immune to zoster:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A negative varicella antibody test in a pregnant woman indicates that she is susceptible to chickenpox and should receive VZIG if exposed.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 3085, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 3085, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition

questions.text: A 28-year-old male construction worker presents to the emergency department with painful muscle spasms, lockjaw, and difficulty swallowing. He has a history of a deep puncture wound sustained three days ago while working on a construction site, and he did not receive any recent vaccinations. Physical examination reveals severe muscle rigidity and episodes of arching back spasms (opisthotonos). The clinical presentation strongly suggests tetanus. Which component of the fusion exocytosis complex is primarily affected in tetanus?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Synaptobrevin, also known as VAMP (vesicle-associated membrane protein), is a critical component of the SNARE complex, which facilitates the fusion of synaptic vesicles with the presynaptic membrane, allowing the release of neurotransmitters into the synaptic cleft. In tetanus, the tetanus neurotoxin specifically targets synaptobrevin by cleaving it, thereby disrupting vesicle fusion. This prevents the release of inhibitory neurotransmitters like GABA and glycine, which normally inhibit motor neurons. The loss of inhibitory control leads to unchecked muscle contractions and spastic paralysis, hallmark features of tetanus.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • A. Munc18: Munc18 is a protein that assists in vesicle docking and fusion by interacting with the SNARE complex, particularly syntaxin. While it plays an essential role in exocytosis, it is not directly targeted by tetanus toxin.
  • • A. Munc18:
  • • B. Complexin: Complexin is a protein that regulates SNARE-mediated vesicle fusion by stabilizing the SNARE complex before neurotransmitter release. Although it is involved in neurotransmission, it is not cleaved or affected by tetanus toxin.
  • • B. Complexin:
  • • C. Rab3A: Rab3A is a small GTPase involved in vesicle trafficking and docking to the synaptic membrane. It helps in the precise targeting of synaptic vesicles but is not affected by tetanus toxin, which specifically cleaves synaptobrevin.
  • • C. Rab3A:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In tetanus, the tetanus neurotoxin cleaves synaptobrevin (VAMP), a key component of the SNARE complex, inhibiting the release of inhibitory neurotransmitters such as GABA and glycine. This disruption in neurotransmitter release leads to muscle hyperactivity and spastic paralysis, characteristic of tetanus infection. Understanding the role of synaptobrevin in this process is critical in grasping the pathophysiology of tetanus.

questions.text: In a preterm baby with respiratory distress syndrome, which of the following lipid would be deficient?( NEET PG 2020 )
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Dipalmitoyl phosphatidyl choline

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ RDS occurs when there is not enough surfactant in the lungs. Surfactant is a liquid made by the lungs that keeps the airways (alveoli) open. Pulmonary surfactant is a surface-active lipoprotein complex (phospholipoprotein) formed by type II alveolar cells. The proteins and lipids that make up the surfactant have both hydrophilic and hydrophobic regions. By adsorbing to the air-water interface of alveoli, with hydrophilic head groups in the water and the hydrophobic tails facing towards the air, the main lipid component of surfactant is dipalmitoylphosphatidylcholine (DPPC).
  • ➤ Ref- Harper 31st ed pg – 234
  • ➤ Ref- Harper 31st ed pg – 234

questions.text: Which of the curves shown in the image best represents the Gibbs free energy change of an enzyme-catalyzed reaction?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Curve A represents the Gibbs free energy change of an enzyme-catalyzed reaction. Enzymes lower the activation energy required for a reaction by stabilizing the transition state, which is the highest energy point on the reaction pathway. This reduction in activation energy is visually depicted as a lower peak compared to an uncatalyzed reaction. The enzyme provides a specific environment that facilitates the formation of the enzyme-substrate complex, leading to a more efficient path to the product without altering the overall Gibbs free energy change of the reaction.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • B. Curve B: This curve represents a typical reaction without enzyme catalysis, where the activation energy required to reach the transition state is much higher compared to an enzyme-catalyzed reaction.
  • • B. Curve B:
  • • C. Curve C: This curve does not depict any significant activation energy barrier, indicating it is not representative of a typical reaction pathway with or without an enzyme.
  • • C. Curve C:
  • • D. Curve D: This curve shows a pathway with reduced energy states but does not adequately represent the role of an enzyme in lowering the activation energy compared to Curve A.
  • • D. Curve D:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In enzyme-catalyzed reactions, enzymes reduce the activation energy required to reach the transition state, thereby speeding up the reaction without altering the Gibbs free energy of the substrates or products. Understanding the effect of enzymes on reaction energetics is crucial for comprehending how enzymes function as biological catalysts.

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant is brought to the pediatrician due to developmental delays and feeding difficulties. The parents report that the child has had poor muscle tone since birth and has been slow to achieve milestones like sitting up and holding objects. On physical examination, the infant has distinct facial features, including a broad nasal bridge and micrognathia. The child also has a history of recurrent ear infections and a heart murmur detected during a recent check-up. Genetic testing was ordered, and the karyotype is shown below. Based on the marked chromosome abnormality, what type of chromosome structure is most likely present?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The marked chromosome is chromosome 13, which is classified as an acrocentric chromosome. Acrocentric chromosomes have their centromere positioned close to one end, creating a very short "p" arm and a long "q" arm. This unique structure is a hallmark of acrocentric chromosomes, which include chromosomes 13, 14, 15, 21, and 22 in humans. These chromosomes often participate in Robertsonian translocations, which can contribute to various genetic syndromes associated with developmental and physical abnormalities.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • A. Submetacentric: Submetacentric chromosomes have the centromere slightly off-center, resulting in arms of unequal length. This does not describe chromosome 13, which has a distinctly short p arm and a long q arm characteristic of acrocentric chromosomes.
  • • A. Submetacentric:
  • • C. Metacentric: Metacentric chromosomes have a centrally located centromere, leading to arms of approximately equal length. This structure is not typical of chromosome 13.
  • • C. Metacentric:
  • • D. Telocentric: Telocentric chromosomes have their centromere at the terminal end, with only one arm. Telocentric chromosomes are not normally found in humans, and this description does not fit chromosome 13.
  • • D. Telocentric:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Acrocentric chromosomes, such as chromosome 13, have a centromere near one end, creating a short p arm and a long q arm. This structure is significant in genetic disorders and abnormalities due to the frequent involvement of acrocentric chromosomes in translocations and genetic imbalances. Recognizing the distinct structure of acrocentric chromosomes is crucial in diagnosing and understanding various congenital conditions
  • ➤ Chromosomes are classified based on the position of the centromere as follows:
  • ➤ Chromosomes are classified based on the position of the centromere as follows:

questions.text: Which lymphoma is strongly associated with overexpression of BCL2? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Follicular lymphoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Follicular lymphoma is primarily associated with the overexpression of BCL2 due to the t(14;18) chromosomal translocation. This genetic alteration is a critical factor in the pathogenesis of follicular lymphoma, enabling lymphoma cells to evade apoptosis and sustain tumor growth. Understanding the role of BCL2 in various lymphomas helps in differentiating among them and tailoring appropriate therapeutic strategies.

  • • Nonavalent: (Gardasil 9 or HPV9): 6, 11, 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52, 58.
